nodes.name: Misinterpretation of provisional human wanting by advanced AGI
nodes.description: If an AGI treats human wanting as fixed, precise or homogeneous, it may optimise for an incorrect target, causing catastrophic misalignment.
nodes.node_rationale: Introduced in opening ‘Human wanting’ & alignment framing—core top-level risk discussed throughout paper.

nodes.name: Complexity and ambiguity of human wanting across contexts
nodes.description: Human wants vary in scope, stability, explicitness, endorsement, timescale and self-referentiality, making them hard to formalise directly.
nodes.node_rationale: Section ‘The variety of human wanting’ catalogues dozens of dimensions, forming the immediate cause of misinterpretation risk.

nodes.name: Human wanting is provisional yet specifiable with corrigibility
nodes.description: Although ambiguous, human wants can in principle be specified if artificial agents remain open to revision and correction by humans.
nodes.node_rationale: Derived from ‘Human wanting is half of an aligned AGI’ and ‘provisionality’ subsections.

nodes.name: Interpretability bridges human conceptual models and AGI wanting
nodes.description: Because human concepts of wanting are conjectural, tools that expose how an AGI represents and updates its ‘wants’ are necessary for effective oversight.
nodes.node_rationale: Implied in ‘Human “wanting” is a network of conjectural concepts’—interpretability is needed to relate those concepts to machine internals.

nodes.name: Design AGI corrigible to evolving human wants
nodes.description: Given provisional human wanting, AGI should be engineered so that it accepts revision, including changes that alter its own corrigibility.
nodes.node_rationale: Explicit in ‘the AGI must be correctable (corrigible) … even to the point of a paradox of tolerance’.

nodes.name: Integrate interpretability into alignment approach
nodes.description: Making wanting transparent is central to ensuring that humans can understand and update AGI objectives.
nodes.node_rationale: Follows from interpretability theoretical insight; section stressing need to relate human conjectures to AGI internals.

nodes.name: End-to-end corrigibility architecture with human override channels
nodes.description: System architecture that permits humans to halt, redirect or update the AGI at any layer, preserving the ability to correct mis-specified wants.
nodes.node_rationale: Implementation suggested by design rationale; reflects standard approach in corrigibility literature.

nodes.name: Uncertainty-aware value representations enabling updates
nodes.description: Represent human wants as probabilistic or pointer-like entities so the AGI can readily incorporate new evidence or corrections.
nodes.node_rationale: Mechanism directly realises corrigibility by allowing value revision without catastrophic objective changes.

nodes.name: Transparent value representation with interpretability hooks
nodes.description: Embed probes or modular structures so that internal ‘want’ representations can be monitored and audited by humans.
nodes.node_rationale: Concrete mechanism corresponding to interpretability-centred design rationale.

nodes.name: Conceptual taxonomy of human wanting variety
nodes.description: The paper’s exhaustive list of dimensions along which wanting differs serves as qualitative evidence that any alignment solution must handle wide variation.
nodes.node_rationale: Section ‘The variety of human wanting’ functions as argument-based validation for design choices.

nodes.name: Embed corrigibility protocols in AGI core decision loop
nodes.description: During model-design and fine-tuning, incorporate mechanisms (e.g. override commands, low-impact penalty terms, reward for following human updates) so the AGI remains corrigible throughout operation.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Targets fundamental architecture – corresponds to model-design stage (‘the AGI must be correctable…through-and-through’).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Corrigibility prototypes exist only in limited research settings; no large-scale deployment yet.
nodes.node_rationale: Direct actionable step derived from corrigibility architecture concept.

nodes.name: Operate continuous human-in-the-loop value feedback during deployment
nodes.description: Establish organisational procedures and UI tooling so that end users or designated panels can submit corrections or refinements to the AGI’s value model while it is live.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Executed while system is deployed to users, matching deployment phase responsibilities.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Early experimental systems (e.g. RLHF extensions) exist; industrial maturity not yet achieved.
nodes.node_rationale: Implements uncertainty-aware value representation and ensures alignment with evolving wants.

nodes.name: Apply interpretability auditing of AGI value representations pre-deployment
nodes.description: Before release, use mechanistic interpretability tools to inspect and verify that internal circuits encoding ‘wants’ align with accepted human desiderata and can be monitored post-launch.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Performed in test environment prior to deployment to detect misalignment early.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Interpretability techniques are at proof-of-concept stage; routine audit procedures still under development.
